newsitem.title: USA: US retail sales mixed, weather hurts apparel.
newsitem.headline: US retail sales mixed, weather hurts apparel.

text.p: U.S. retailers reported mixed results for April, with cold weather curbing the consumer appetite for spring apparel, analysts said.
"They (U.S. retailer sales reports) seemed overall a little disappointing," S&P Equity Group analyst Karen Sack said. "People were not ready to buy spring merchandise."
For example, Limited Inc reported a five percent drop in April same store sales, and Gap Inc's April same store sales fell six percent.
Limited shares were up 1/4 at 19, while Gap's stock declined 1/2 to 31-1/4.

"Late winter storms may have contributed to weakness in some regions of the country, but in an environment where consumer confidence is high and disposable income is up, it appears shoppers are unmoved by what they see on store shelves," Bernice Behar, senior vice president and portfolio manager for John Hancock Funds, said in a statement.

Despite an extra selling day in April -- since the Easter holiday fell in March in 1997 compared with April in 1996 -- luxury retailers' results were disappointing, said Dillon, Reed analyst Peter Schaeffer.
Saks Holdings Inc's same-store sales rose 0.6 percent, while Neiman Marcus Group Inc posted a 0.3 percent drop in comparable revenues. Saks shares were up 5/8 at 20-5/8 and Neiman fell 3/8 to 25-5/8.

Among the companies reporting sales gains were Sears, Roebuck and Co, which saw a 3.4 percent increase in domestic same store sales on top of a 10.9 percent increase a year ago. Dayton Hudson Corp's Target discount department chain posted a 6.7 percent rise in same store sales in April. Sears shares were up 1/4 at 50 and Dayton shares gained 3/4 to 47-7/8.
